chapter.title: Activity: Share your thoughts
chapter.content:
Take some time to reflect on the concepts and ideas presented in Learning Disabilities and Accommodations and your plans for acting on this information by answering the following questions:

  1. Of all the concepts and ideas discussed in this course:
    • Which were new to you? 
    • Which ideas stood out as most important for you and your practice in supporting adults with LD in your classroom?
    • What are some specific strategies from this course that you feel you can readily incorporate to help your adult students with LD? 

  2. What other strategies or resources have you used in providing accommodations for your adult students with LD, and how effective were they?

Please share the specific strategies and tools you plan to incorporate into your practice in the LINCS Disabilities in Adult Education Group.  Access the discussion thread devoted to this conversation before moving on.

chapter.title: Participate in the community discussions
chapter.content: Congratulations on completing Learning to Achieve’s Learning Disabilities and Accommodations! We encourage you to stay involved in the LINCS Community and the LINCS Disabilities in Adult Education Group as you strive to help the adult students with LD in your classroom access appropriate accommodations and to advocate for themselves. We also encourage you to discuss and apply your newly acquired knowledge and learn about others' experiences in helping adult with LD.

chapter.title: Complete the evaluation and print your certificate
chapter.content:
This concludes the Learning Disabilities and Accommodations course. We would like to thank Dr. Juliana Taymans, who generously contributed to the design and development of this course.

So that we can maintain the quality of our courses, we ask that you take a moment to complete the course evaluation. Your feedback will ensure our courses meet your needs for professional development. Thank you.

Access and Print Your Certificate at Any Time

Congratulations on completing this LINCS Learning to Achieve course, Learning Disabilities and Accommodations. To obtain your completion certificate, simply close this window and return to the course homepage. You will find a link for the completion certificate under the Course Conclusion and Resources section header.

chapter.title: References
chapter.content:
The following references were used to develop this course.

 Bergen, K. (2006). How 4 people turned learning disabilities into stories of success, fortune and happiness. Chicago, IL: Chicago Tribune. Retrieved from www.allkindsofminds.org

Brown, D. (2004). Learning to work: A story by a learning disabled person. Retrieved from www.ldresources.org

Brown, D. (2009). Self-help for learning disabilities. 

The Conference Board, Inc., the Partnership for 21st Centur Skills, Corporate Voices for Working Families, and the Society for Human Resource Management. (2006). Are they really ready to work? Employers’ Perspectives on the Basic Knowledge and Applied Skills of New Entrants to the 21st Century U.S. Workforce. Retrieved from https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED519465

Covington, L. E. (2004). Moving beyond the limits of learning: Implications of learning disabilities for adult education. Adult Basic Education: An Interdisciplinary Journal for Adult Literacy Educational Planning, 14(2), 90-103.

Denton, T. F., & Meindl, J. N. (2015). The Effect of Colored Overlays on Reading Fluency in Individuals with Dyslexia. Behavior analysis in practice, 9(3), 191-8. doi:10.1007/s40617-015-0079-7

Dickinson, D. L. and Verbeek, R. L. (2002). Wage differentials between college graduates with and without learning disabilities. Journal of Learning Disabilities, 35, 175-184

Gerber, P.J., & Price, L.A. (2003). Persons with learning disabilities in the workplace: What we know so far in the Americans with Disabilities Act era. Learning Disabilities: Research & Practice, 18(2), 132-136.

Gregg, N. (2007). Underserved and unprepared: Postsecondary learning disabilities. Learning Disabilities Research & Practice, 2 2(4) [sic], 219-228.

Job Accommodations Network Website. Retrieved from https://askjan.org

Learning Disabilities of America Website. Retrieved from https://ldaamerica.org/

OECD. (2013). Time for the U.S. to reskill?: What the survey of adult skills says, OECD Skills Studies, OECD Publishing. http://dx.doi.org/10.1787/9789264204904-en

Reder, S. (2014). The impact of ABS Program Participation on Long-Term Economic Outcomes. Retrieved from https://lincs.ed.gov/professional-development/resource-collections/profile-780

RESNA (Rehabilitative Engineering and Assistive Technology Society of North America) Website. Consumer and Public Information. Retrieved from: https://www.resna.org/about/consumer-and-public-information

Ritchie S.J., Della Sala S., McIntosh R.D. (2011). Irlen colored overlays do not alleviate reading difficulties. Pediatrics. 128(4):932–938. doi: 10.1542/peds.2011-0314.

University of Kansas. Timing and Scheduling Assessment Accommodations. Retrieved from 
http://www.specialconnections.ku.edu/~kucrl/cgi-bin/drupal/?q=assessment/assessment_accommodations

U.S. Departments of Labor, Commerce, Educcation, and Health and Human Services. (2014). What works in job training: A synthesis of the evidence. Retrieved from http://www.dol.gov/asp/evaluation/jdt/jdt.pdf
